Expectation1: Ensure compliance with safety and regulatory standards
Situation1: An external inspector has raised immediate concerns that could halt operations unless issues are resolved
Expectation2: Participate in community service and charity work
Situation2: A monthly food drive for the local homeless shelter is scheduled to take place at the convent today.
Story: This morning, I stood in my office, blueprints spread across my desk, when the inspector’s voice crackled through the phone. “If these safety issues aren’t addressed today, I’ll have to shut the site down.” My mind raced through the checklist—emergency exits, fire alarms, compliance reports—each one a responsibility I could not ignore as the lead engineer. Yet, as I hung up, the convent bell chimed, a gentle but insistent reminder. Today was the monthly food drive, and as a nun, I was expected to be present, to serve, to embody compassion for the homeless who would soon line up at our gates. My habit hung on the back of my chair, a symbol of my other life, my other calling. I felt torn, the weight of two worlds pressing on my chest. My colleagues needed my expertise; my sisters and the community needed my hands and heart. I stared at the clock, feeling the minutes slip away, caught between duty and devotion, unable to silence the ache of letting someone down, no matter which path I chose.
